Completion Prompts: Identify one non-dilutive option to explore further.
Name one strategic milestone that justifies raising capital.
Capture one autonomy safeguard to prioritize in funding talks.

Related Protocols: Cost Lines to Bless or Cut
Unit Economics as a Living Compass

Overall Outcomes.Excellent: Decision is based on clear strategic, financial, and cultural analysis → The future benefits from capital only when it truly serves the build.
Overall Outcomes.Expected: Some analysis done, but emotional or external pressure drives the decision → The future gains some benefit, but with preventable trade-offs.
Overall Outcomes.Poor: Decision to raise is made reactively or from fear of missing out → The future risks misalignment and wasted dilution.
Overall Outcomes.Transcendent: Funding necessity is evaluated as cultural reflex—capital is used as a precise tool, never a default → The future compounds both autonomy and impact.

Overall Purpose: To determine whether raising external capital is truly necessary, or if alternative strategies can achieve current goals without taking on investor constraints.

Guiding Questions: What would this capital allow us to do that we cannot do otherwise?
Is that worth the trade-offs of raising?
Are there other ways to achieve the same outcome?
Themes.Name: Clarifying the Strategic Purpose of Capital

Excellent.Edge condition: You tie capital to specific milestones.
Excellent.Present pattern: Clear, prioritized connection between funding and strategic outcomes.
Excellent.Signals: Everyone can state exactly why we’d raise.

Expected.30-90 day system effect: Capital supports some, but not all, key priorities.
Expected.Edge condition: You mix essential and non-essential uses.
Expected.Example moves: Including wish list items in use-of-funds.
Expected.Present pattern: Some strategic link, but not quantified or prioritized.

Poor.Edge condition: You raise because it seems like the next step.
Poor.Present pattern: No clear link between funding and strategy.

Transcendent.Edge condition: You reject raises without tight alignment.
Transcendent.Present pattern: Strategic clarity on capital use is cultural instinct.

Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To identify exactly what raising money would make possible that cannot be done otherwise.
Themes.Why This Matters: If the purpose isn’t clear, capital risks being used inefficiently or without impact.

Guiding Questions: What non-dilutive options could meet our needs?
How would these compare in cost and impact to equity?
What mix of funding could balance growth and control?
Themes.Name: Exploring Non-Dilutive Alternatives

Excellent.Present pattern: Viable non-dilutive options are explored alongside equity.

Expected.Edge condition: You overestimate the difficulty of non-dilutive options.
Expected.Example moves: Skipping grant applications due to time cost.
Expected.Present pattern: Some alternatives considered, but not pursued seriously.

Poor.Edge condition: You assume all capital must come from investors.
Poor.Present pattern: Equity raising is considered the only option.

Transcendent.Edge condition: You treat ownership as a strategic asset.

Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To examine whether partnerships, revenue strategies, or other funding models could meet needs without selling equity.
Themes.Why This Matters: Non-dilutive options can preserve control and ownership while still enabling growth.

Guiding Questions: What are the total costs—financial, cultural, and strategic—of this raise?
How do they compare to the benefits?
Can we achieve our goals with less cost?
Themes.Name: Understanding the True Cost of Capital

Excellent.Present pattern: Full picture of capital costs understood and weighed.

Expected.Edge condition: You prioritize cheque size over terms.
Expected.Example moves: Agreeing to governance shifts for funding.
Expected.Present pattern: Some cost factors considered, but not comprehensively.

Poor.Present pattern: Cost of capital considered only in financial terms.

Transcendent.30-90 day system effect: Capital enhances capacity without eroding control.
Transcendent.Future effect: Growth is always on our terms.
Transcendent.Present pattern: Cost–benefit analysis of capital is cultural instinct.

Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To evaluate both the visible and hidden costs of taking on outside funding.
Themes.Why This Matters: Capital comes with expectations, dilution, and potential constraints—underestimating the cost can damage autonomy and flexibility.

Guiding Questions: Is now the right season to raise?
Do we have readiness in place to use capital effectively?
How does this match our natural growth rhythm?
Themes.Name: Matching Funding to Pace and Season

Excellent.Edge condition: You plan raise to match readiness milestones.
Excellent.Present pattern: Raise timing matches readiness and growth needs.

Expected.Example moves: Raise in off-season for core market.
Expected.Present pattern: Some attention to timing, but reactive.

Poor.30-90 day system effect: Capital sits idle or is burned too fast.
Poor.Edge condition: You chase timing that works for investors.
Poor.Immediate cost: Misfit between funding and execution capacity.
Poor.Present pattern: Raise timing based on investor availability, not readiness.
Poor.Signals: Raising before product–market fit or too late in runway.

Transcendent.Example moves: Embedded pacing check in funding decisions.
Transcendent.Future effect: Rhythm and capital work as one.

Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To align capital decisions with the organization’s natural growth rhythm and current stage.
Themes.Why This Matters: Raising too early or too late can create strain, waste, or missed opportunities.

Guiding Questions: How will this raise affect our control?
What’s the autonomy cost of saying yes?
Themes.Name: Protecting Autonomy Through Capital Decisions

Expected.Future effect: Control at risk in future raises.
Expected.Present pattern: Some autonomy safeguards in place, but gaps remain.

Poor.Present pattern: Autonomy risks ignored in funding decisions.

Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To safeguard decision-making power and mission integrity when evaluating funding.
Themes.Why This Matters: Capital that compromises autonomy can distort direction and culture.

Title: Do We Need to Raise?
When To Use This Protocol:
When considering a new funding round
When pressure to raise comes from external stakeholders
When evaluating multiple growth paths
When wanting to protect autonomy and flexibility
Why This Matters: Raising money can accelerate growth—but it also brings obligations, expectations, and potential loss of control. Many companies raise when they could instead optimize, partner, or pace themselves.
